Viewing a summary of every column

Often, the main information that youâ€™re interested in is the summary of each column. You can compute this yourself (as weâ€™ll show later), but there is also a nice package called summarytools that can generate a handy overview. You can create the summary as follows (remember to install the package first):

library(summarytools)
dfSummary(d)

This will print the summary in your console, but you can also render it in a more readable format with the view function.

view(dfSummary(d))

2024-08-26

Using summarytools in Quarty or RMarkdown

If youâ€™re working in Quarto or RMarkdown, the normal way of using summarytools doesnâ€™t create a nice table. Instead, what you need to do is tell Quarto to render the output as HTML. You can do this by setting the method argument to render.

print(dfSummary(iris), 
      method='render', 
      max.tbl.height = 500)

Note that we also set the max.tbl.height argument to 500, to make sure that very large tables are put inside a scrollable window.
